title: 112_hr4485
content: The "Credible Military Option to Counter Iran Act" includes sections on the short title, declaration of policy, US military preparedness in the Middle East, military capabilities in the Central Command Area of Responsibility, defense of Israel and US interests, enhancing Persian Gulf allies' military capabilities, increasing strategic regional partnerships, and definitions. Iran is exploiting political transitions in the Middle East to support extremist movements and undermine US-aligned governments. Concerns are rising over Iran's potential nuclear weapons capability, which could threaten US interests, destabilize the region, and encourage nuclear proliferation. Iran's support has bolstered Syria, Hezbollah, and Hamas in recent years. Iran, Syria, Hezbollah, and Hamas have increased their stockpiles of rockets, with over 60,000 rockets aimed at Israel. Iran is also expanding its arsenal of ballistic and cruise missiles, posing a threat to its neighbors, Israel, and US forces in the region. Preventing Iran from obtaining nuclear weapons is a top national security priority for the United States, with successive administrations declaring it unacceptable. President Obama emphasized the determination to stop Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons in 2012. The United States, along with its allies, must use all elements of national power to prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons, including diplomacy, economic sanctions, and military preparations. Despite diplomatic efforts and sanctions, Iran has not abandoned its nuclear program. Additional pressure may be needed, including the credible threat of military action. It is the policy of the United States to take all necessary measures, including military action if required, to prevent Iran from threatening the country. The United States and its allies must use all elements of national power to prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons, including diplomacy, economic sanctions, and military preparations. Additional pressure, including the credible threat of military action, may be necessary to prevent Iran from threatening the United States, its allies, or its neighbors with a nuclear weapon. The United States emphasizes military preparedness in the Middle East to prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons. The sense of Congress is to conduct military exercises in the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman to enhance readiness and signal commitment to defend national security interests. The President should require a plan to increase the presence of the Fifth Fleet in the Middle East and conduct visible military activities to underscore US policy. The Secretary of Defense is tasked with preparing a plan to augment the presence of the US Fifth Fleet in the Middle East through military deployments and readiness activities. This plan includes pre-positioning supplies and maintaining naval assets in key locations. The plan involves maintaining naval assets in the region to signal US resolve, deploying aircraft carriers and amphibious ships continually, and conducting naval fleet exercises to bolster capabilities and protect interests in the Middle East. The United States Fifth Fleet conducted a major exercise in March 2007 to demonstrate its ability to keep the Strait of Hormuz open and counter threats from anti-ship missiles and high-speed boats. The plan required by Congress must be submitted within 120 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. United States military capabilities in the Central Command area of responsibility. Authorization of Appropriations for Fiscal Year 2012 includes funds for enhancing US military capabilities in the Central Command Area of Responsibility. This includes $80 million for MK 38 Mod 2 machine gun system, $44.6 million for Griffin missile and Spike shoulder-fired weapon procurement, and $72.5 million for research and development projects such as digital rocket launchers and beyond line of sight command and control architecture. Authorization of Appropriations for Fiscal Year 2013 includes funding for various military programs such as Hard and Deeply Buried Target Defeat System, Indications and Warning, Systems Performance, Scan Eagle, and tactics development and evaluation. For fiscal year 2013, funding includes $22,654,000 for Other Procurement, Navy for Underwater Explosive Ordnance Disposal, Naval Military Intelligence Program Support Equipment, and MK 38 Mod 2 machine gun system for Coastal Patrol Craft. Additionally, $31,000,000 is allocated for Weapons Procurement, Navy for Griffin missile for Coastal Patrol Craft and Spike shoulder-fired electro-optic weapon. Research, Development, Test and Evaluation, Army receives $72,481,000 for Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Detection and Tracking, while Research, Development, Test and Evaluation, Navy gets the same amount for Joint Service Explosive Ordnance Development. For fiscal year 2013, $72,481,000 is allocated for Research, Development, Test and Evaluation, Air Force for Cyber Command Activities within Program Element 0208059F, including Joint Service Explosive Ordnance Development, Advanced Anti-Radiation Guided Missile, and Integrated, Fixed Surveillance System. SEC. 5. ENHANCING DEFENSE OF ISRAEL AND US INTERESTS IN THE MIDDLE EAST. Sense of Congress: The United States should provide support to Israel for the development and production of joint missile defense systems, defense articles, intelligence, and defense services. This includes air refueling tankers, missile defense capabilities, specialized munitions, additional weaponry and munitions for the US stockpile in Israel, and surplus defense articles and services following the withdrawal of US forces from Iraq. The United States should support Israel in developing joint missile defense systems, defense articles, and intelligence. This includes offering additional training to the Israeli Air Force in the US, expanding Israel's purchasing authority under the Arms Export Control Act, enhancing security cooperation, and encouraging Israel's role in NATO. Additionally, the US should extend the loan guarantee program for Israel. The United States should support Israel in developing joint missile defense systems, defense articles, and intelligence. This includes expanding intelligence cooperation, preserving Israel's qualitative military edge, and encouraging advanced technology programs between the two countries. The President must submit reports to congressional committees on Israel's military edge, F-35 aircraft purchases, cooperation in defense areas, and integration into Eastern Mediterranean defense within 180 days of this Act's enactment. SEC. 6. PLAN TO ENHANCE MILITARY CAPABILITIES OF PERSIAN GULF ALLIES. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of State, will develop a plan to enhance the military capabilities of Persian Gulf allies to strengthen their posture in relation to Iran. This plan includes augmenting offensive strike capabilities, updating military requirements, and improving self-defense capabilities against potential aggression from Iran. The plan developed by the Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of State, aims to support Gulf allies in enhancing their military capabilities to defend against potential aggression from Iran. This includes arms sales, training requests, and ensuring Israel's qualitative military edge is maintained. The plan must be submitted to Congress within 180 days in an unclassified form, with a possible classified annex. The plan developed by the Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of State, aims to increase strategic regional partnerships. The United States aims to have a broad set of geographic approaches to access Iran, including from Azerbaijan's northern border. This policy includes increasing pressure on Iran and exploring ways to enhance military facilities on the northern border. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of State, is developing a plan to increase strategic partnerships with regional allies to provide the US Armed Forces with various geographic approaches to access Iran, including potentially utilizing bases in Azerbaijan. The plan includes mechanisms to broaden access, strengthening self-defense capabilities of allies, and assessing the viability of using bases in Azerbaijan. The Secretary of Defense is developing a plan to increase strategic partnerships with regional allies, including potentially using bases in Azerbaijan to augment military options. The plan must be submitted to congress within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms used in the Act, such as "appropriate congressional committees," "congressional defense committees," and "qualitative military edge."
